fields.description: Whenever choosing a commit or opening a different repo, in the history work space, all files are automatically selected. This appears to cause a massive halt in usability. *SourceTree can become unresponsive (beach ball) for 15+ seconds* on a commit with any decent amount of files changed. This was not a problem previously, and is not a problem when selecting commits with only a few files changed. This makes looking through commits to find changes impractical at best, and impossible at worse, makes opening different repos a massive pain, and at times borderline unusable.
fields.summary: All files Automatically selected when selecting a commit (Massive performance hit)

fields.description:
In my experience, people rarely switch themes in themeable apps. It's a personal preference (especially light vs. dark) and once you pick one you stick with it. So the UI affordance for theme switching will be very rarely used.

Thus, this seems more appropriate as a setting in the prefs, rather than having it take up space in the View menu (at the top, even.)
fields.summary: Theme selector should be a pref, not a menu item

fields.description:
In the Diffs pref pane, all four colo[u]r wells display black. Worse, as soon as this pane is opened, the colors in actual diffs all change to black, so there's no more highlighting of changes.
 # First launch of 2.6 beta (was running 2.5)
 # Opened a repo and selected a commit; diff colors are somewhat different than before but visible.
 # Opened Prefs
 # Clicked "Diff" tab; all four color wells display black swatches.
 # Looked at repo window; colors in diff pane are now gone.

I configured the colors again in the prefs, and they do show up now, although I had to refresh the diff view by switching to a different file.
fields.summary: Diff colors show as black in prefs and are reset to black
Unable to push a text file to bitbucket

fields.description: When I want to pull a git-lfs content via Sourcetree the password dialog pops out. When I put a correct password and check the "store in keychain" checkbox it still prompts for password. Maybe it is asking that for every file? I'm not sure. It is pretty unusable right now.
fields.summary: Sourcetree keeps asking for password (Git-LFS)

fields.description:
[https://confluence.atlassian.com/get-started-with-sourcetree/install-sourcetree-847359094.html]

Page still refers to DMG installable but that is no longer distributed for Mac.
fields.summary: Install documentation still refers to DMG file. Install is now provided as a Zip and is confusing customers.

fields.description:
not a bug, really, but "Nothing to commit" italian translation is "Niente da committare", that is really really terrible.

*Committare* is not a verb in italian, it's a word that doesn’t exist. I think the best translation would be something like "Nessun commit da eseguire"
fields.summary: Italian translation

fields.description:
It's great to see that the "Sign commit" setting is now remembered since SourceTree 2.5. However, now I'm never certain if this setting is even enabled because I'm working with a lot of repositories. So I'm still opening up "Commit Options…" to see if "Sign commit" is enabled.

My suggestion is to show an icon (e.g., padlock) next to "Commit Options…" or the commit history button if "Sign commit" is enabled. If it isn't enabled, don't show the icon.
fields.summary: Show an icon that commit will be signed

fields.description:
Before 2.3.5 you could create mercurial branch names containing spaces.
As of 2.3.5 they are auto-replaced with hyphens which has broken some build processes we use.

Mercurial branch names containing spaces are perfectly valid (I understand this is not the case with git).

Can we at the very least have a preference to enable/disable this recently added feature?

We currently have to create the branches via command line to maintain our branching conventions.

https://community.atlassian.com/t5/SourceTree-questions/Disable-auto-replaces-spaces-with-dashes/qaq-p/600937
fields.summary: Ability to create Mercurial branch names containing spaces

fields.description:
I'm not actually sure if this is a bug in SourceTree or in Bitbucket, but since it's both Atlassian I trust this ticket will find its right place.

When I right-click a feature/... branch in SourceTree, then click 'Create Pull Request...', check the values in the dialog and click 'Create Pull Request On Web', Bitbucket opens in my browser with this error message: "Commit 'feature%2Fmy-branch-name' does not exist in repository 'MyRepo'" (with the correct branch name and repository name, but with the '/' replaced by '%2F').

The url SourceTree seems to have used to get there is this: https://bitbucket.example.com/projects/mr/repos/myrepo/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=feature%252Fmy-branch-name

Note the '%252F' in that url, seems like a case of double url encoding in SourceTree where only single url decoding is applied by Bitbucket. If I change the url to [https://bitbucket.example.com/projects/mr/repos/myrepo/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=feature%2Fmy-branch-name] the feature works correctly.
fields.summary: pull request to Bitbucket with branch name containing '/' does not work

fields.description: When upgrading from one version of ST to another (via the application menu), ST downloads the new version all over again (some 58Mb or so) even if the new version has already been downloaded (e.g. by a previous failed upgrade). This seems wasteful especially for people on slow connections.
fields.summary: Don't re-download upgrade if installation fails

fields.description:
When committing renamed files after pushing I get the new files remote but locally I have the files with the old names and I have to make another commit to delete them from origin.

This happened on Mac and Windows on two different projects.
fields.summary: Not committing renamed files correctly

fields.description: When drag SourceTree window around the screen, the window blinks and jumps.
fields.summary: SourceTree for Mac blinks and jumps
diff Not work properly when using DeltaWalker as SourceTree's custom external diff

fields.description:
Check screenshot.
If I press SPACE, the item is not toggled to SELECTED.
fields.summary: Items can not be selected pressing SPACE key

fields.description:
SourceTree crashes at opening a repository from bookmarks list (or if the repository window was open at last session and I start SourceTree). From last session still history view is open, SourcTree tries automatically to get the preview for all files of marked folder (first position in tree view) of the latest commit. It's not possible to select a single file, change view or anything else. The preview loads very long and crashes.

Maybe quick workaround: Is it possible to change view type from terminal before opening the repository? How?
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on opening repository in history view (tree view)

fields.description:
With ≥ 2 tabs open in the SourceTree window, the split view positioning will fail to be preserved and/or restored for the first tab.

STR:
 # Open two tabs in a ST window (each for a different repo, for example).
 # Select “History” view mode in each.
 # Arrange the bottom split views (commit message, file list, and diff) in a conspicuous manner.
 # Quit ST, and then re-launch.

Expected:

Split view arrangement will be restored to what it was when ST was quit.

Actual:

If the first tab was active at quit time, the split view arrangement is random, different from how it was left.

In contrast, if the second tab was active at quit time, its split view position is properly restored.

This is really annoying.
fields.summary: Fails to save/restore split view positioning for first of several tabs

fields.description:
On the Community Forums it was suggested I write a ticket for this, so here it is:

I found a "Format To Guidelines" option in the contextual menu of the commit message box. I thought that might be a handy way to format my commit messages with autowrap to the guideline bar (currently at 72 characters).

So far, I haven't gotten the option to do anything.

This brings up a bunch of questions:
 # Is it supposed to operate on the entire text of the buffer?
 # Is it supposed to just work on selected text?
 # Is it a toggle?  If so, there's no check mark in the contextual menu to indicate whether it's off or on.

In any case, no matter what I've tried to do (including the list above), I haven't seen the option do anything.
fields.summary: SourceTree format to guidelines in commit message doesn't do anything

fields.description: When a branch is set for closure (during PR creation) then merged (and therefore automatically closed) it would be great if SourceTree notified you that the branch had been closed remotely and ask for confirmation of deletion locally. Otherwise you end up with dozens of orphaned branches locally and it can be difficult to keep track.
fields.summary: Receive notification of branch closure and option to locally remove branch

fields.description:
Hi Team,

Not able to start source tree after I downloaded the latest version *2.5.2*

*Error Text:*

The SourceTree application you are running is less than the current version required. Please work to move to SourceTree version 2.5.1+.

Please help in resolving the same. Since I already download 2.5.1+ version, i don't know which version would fix this issue.

 

Thanks,

Abhilash
fields.summary: SourceTree Application Launch issue
Source Tree Doesnt start on Mac Sierra

fields.description:
Hi guys.
I have the branch XXX, and I merged MASTER over XXX.
XXX now has conflicts.
I all conflicts removing all those <<< and >>>, leaving only what I need.
I didn't mark file as solved. I try to STAGE HUNKs and I'm guetting this issue (check screenshot).
fields.summary: Error why trying to "Stage Hunk" in a file that has a conflict

fields.description: In a Mac with multiple displays connected, Sourcetree app always open in main display. Other apps remember which display they were open/closed in the last time, but for some reason, Sourcetree does not.
fields.summary: App in Mac with multiple displays keeps showing in main display

fields.description: I am not sure if this is not yet fixed in newer versions, but when I try to edit details of the subtree that is linked to any custom branch, it automatically switches to master when the dialog form is loaded.
fields.summary: Subtree details editing switches to the master branch automatically

fields.description:
New `New branch` which appeared in 2.5.3 automatically lowercases new branch names with no way to prevent this.

This is against workflows some people are used to, and I'm not sure there are strict Git specs around this. At least make it configurable please.
fields.summary: `New branch` automatically lowercases branch names

fields.description:
New Branch screen (which appeared in 2.5.3) layout is broken severely for long branch names.

Please see the gif attached.
fields.summary: New `create branch` layout is broken for long branch names

fields.description:
Being able to resizing the merge dialog, One would expect to be able to view more of the code tree or file(s) view. But that view is fixed. 

 

As a user I would like to be able to see more of this view when running merges.
fields.summary: Merge Popup doesn't resize code view properly

fields.description:
The issue isn't around for long, probably a few weeks. Every time I want to commit changes, I have to wait about 10 seconds for SourceTree to load the file changes until it lets me click on "uncommitted changes". Sometimes the selection snaps back to the last commit and I have to click "uncommitted changes" again and wait once more.
 It appears to happen across all my [remote] repos.

 

---

Issue

commits are taking ~10seconds to load the file changes.
h3. Info Gathered
 # Customer is facing same issue with big repos (650MB) and small repos (100MB).
 # We switched to System Git but the issue persists.
 # Asked the customer to attach a sample of activity monitor into this ticket
 # From this log we can see the error below, but I’m not sure if this is related:
{code:java}
2017-04-25 19:14:58 +0000 (e) [GIT] Unable to write file 'conVela Trade/NewsViewController.swift' at revision 04d6396514b8a323e03af20af3ea7b01ee4c51f5 to /var/folders/9y/vsz76r2x71jfzsjt52knw_5h0000gn/T//conVela Trade_NewsViewController_After_04d6396514b8a323e03af20af3ea7b01ee4c51f5.swift: fatal: Not a valid object name 04d6396514b8a323e03af20af3ea7b01ee4c51f5:conVela Trade/NewsViewController.swift
{code}

I need help to understand what is causing this slowness.
fields.summary: Really slow when clicking on "uncommitted changes" in file status

fields.description:
Branch creation ignores the capital letters I use since the 2.5.3 update.

My branches are named after their JIRA tickets so I like to use capital letters for this. It's kind of a unofficial company guideline to do so.

The release notes only says something about auto replacing spaces with dashes, so my guess is this is something that was overlooked with the new update?
fields.summary: Can't use capital letters in branch creation

fields.description:
Hi,

 Where do I find sourcetree 2.5.1 installable for MAC. Latest download from sourcetree.app is 2.5.2b which i donot need at the moment. Please provide a location where i can download 2.5.1 for MAC.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Download

fields.description:
Hi 

Another day another problem with Source tree - I really wish you guys would stop updating it or add some automated testing for accounts with two factor.. 

Clearly its not being tested. 

The only way to push the key properly - is to add it to the agent via the command line and push it using the terminal ( thats how I managed to get the key working - but defeats the purpose of using sourcetree)

I thought I would try again now that I have some time - and its still not working.  

 Currently it appears that when you go through the process of generating a key - and signing in via Github - the key doesn't appear to be used when you push branches to Github. 

 

Based on the SSH screen - 

!image-2017-06-10-16-36-03-541.png!
fields.summary: Why does sourcetree for Mac not work with Github

fields.description:
When attempting to stage or unstage individual hunks in some files, I get the error “'git apply' failed with code 128:'fatal: unrecognized input
'” (yes the dialog message contains the newline and dangling single quote). If I try to stage individual lines, I get the same error. I can stage and unstage without error by clicking the checkbox next to the filename; this works on both the entire file as one unit and to manipulate all the remaining hunks of a file after I’ve staged selected ones.

There’s no obvious pattern on content: in one case two hunks differ only by variable name, and yet one works while the other gives an error. It seems consistent in that a hunk that produces an error will always produce an error, both within the same session and in older/newer versions of SourceTree.

Workaround: use the checkbox to stage/unstage entire files, though that doesn’t help if you really want to separate out individual hunks.

Found in SourceTree-Beta Version 2.5.3 (113)
Confirmed in SourceTree Version 2.5 (104)
OS X 10.11.5 “El Capitan” (15F34)
fields.summary: Staging/unstaging individual chunks sometimes gives git apply error 128

fields.description: It keeps refreshing. By that I mean like if it was detecting a change in my code and refreshes the windows to show the latest changes. But I'm not updating my code and while I'm reviewing my commits it keeps refreshing and I takes me to the top everything single time!
fields.summary: Keeps Refreshing

fields.description:
Sourcetree can see the repo and the branches, but Git-Pull fails with the following error:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree fetch origin 

remote: Invalid username or password. If you log in via a third party service you must ensure you have an account password set in your account profile.

fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://bitbucket.org/andainc/anda-ecom/src/'

remote: Invalid username or password. If you log in via a third party service you must ensure you have an account password set in your account profile.

fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://bitbucket.org/andainc/anda-ecom/src/'

remote: Invalid username or password. If you log in via a third party service you must ensure you have an account password set in your account profile.
fields.summary: Unable to complete Git pull with validated Atlassian account

fields.description:
Guys,

Do this Steps to reproduce the issue (come on! it's not an expected behavior/feature!)

 
 * Open SourceTree in the panel to create repo
 * Select REMOTE
 * Select a Repo
 * Change the Destination Path
 * Change the Source URL. Then, the Destination path will be updated.

Bug: If I changed the Destination Path, the Source URL should not change.

 

Check GIF
fields.summary: When cloning a remote repo, after changing the URL, the Destination Path change automatically

fields.description:
I have been trying to split & manage development of our local code modules with the git submodules & subtree features ... but in the end both of them did have major drawbacks and added way to much overhead to the general git workflow and maintaining of the version control itself.

A good effort to solve the issues & drawbacks that come with using submodules and git subtree has been made by git-subrepo ([https://github.com/ingydotnet/git-subrepo]) and I am starting to use it more and more for the benefit of avoiding the drawbacks of the other two mentioned subrepo methods.

Would there be a way to integrate the CLI features of git-subrepo into SourceTree ? either via adding some extensibility API and letting the open source community implement the integration of the git-subrepo workflow or via an integrated support for this kind of subrepo workflow ?

Thanks & Regards,
Israel Lins

 

 

carbon copy from Wolfgang SRCTREEWIN-5489
fields.summary: Support for git-subrepo

fields.description:
There is no possibility to chose branch for hotfix, options are disabled.

!Screenshot 2017-06-08 17.43.23.png!
fields.summary: Git flow bug - can't chose branch for hotfix

fields.description: When opening the Merge window, the top row of commits is cut off, almost invisible. It is probably a simple padding issue
fields.summary: Merge window cuts off top row of text
Disable preview pane
Temporary file usage

fields.description:
The problem is anytime I click on ay part of the tree I get this same behavior. I can't right-click on folders to reset them because the right click menu takes an age to load.

You should be able to reproduce this easily by putting a large number of files into a repository, then highlighting a bunch of them in the unstaged view. It seems Sourcetree tries to generate a bunch of previews but just can't cope leading to beach-balling.
fields.summary: Slowness on Sourcetree

fields.description:
We seem to have a problem with sourcetree on mac and windows machines that are not able to see all of the remote repos on the bitbucket server

I have the same problem on my mac running sourcetree version 2.5.1 (105) and my account is admin on the bitbucket server

Bitbucket version: v4.14.2

Please let me know if you need any more info from me
fields.summary: SourceTree not seeing all repos on Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
SourceTree is crashing while trying to remove 3000+ files, removes about  ~500 files and crash.

Repeated the process several times to remove all the needed files
fields.summary: SourceTree on Mac is crashing while trying to remove selection of 3000+files
Forums use wrong name

fields.description:
I was having this problem several versions ago (looking back it was version 2.0.5, reported as SRCTREE-3309), it mysteriously went away, and has now resurfaced in 2.5.1 (not sure if it was in 2.5 or not, but is definitely in 2.5.2.)

When I try to do an interactive rebase, when SourceTree goes to repaint commit history I get a dialog box displayed three times (attached), followed by a mostly empty window of commits (attached), and it remains this way until I do my work from the command-line or from magit (emacs). This is a major pain, as I do a lot of interactive rebasing, and SourceTree is my tool of choice.

 

Can you advise?  Thanks!
fields.summary: Errors during interactive rebase (possible regression)

fields.description:
Usually branch names are shown in a bold font when they are currently checked out. If the branch name contains an umlaut like ä, ü, ö this does not happen. I haven't tried other special characters but there might be some more (ß) that cause this behaviour.

I would provide a screenshot but JIRA is complaining about a missing token right now. But I guess the description is fairly obvious ;)
fields.summary: Checked out branch name not bold when it contains umlauts

fields.description: When attempting to merge, the list of available commits seems to be in a panel too tall for the drawer in which it appears. The more recent commits are not selectable. See attached video.
fields.summary: GUI bug in merge operation

fields.description:
Hi,

I have configured the following settings in my bitbucket repo:
 # Project > Settings > Permissions > Default Permission (=No access)
 # Project > Settings > Permissions > All users/groups except the Admin users/groups should be granted Read access
 # Repository > Create branch > develop (branch-type: Custom, branch-from: develop, branch-name: develop)
 # Repository > Repository permissions > All users/groups except the Admin users/groups should be granted Write access
 # Repository > Branch permissions > Add permissions > Branch name (=master) , Restrictions (=Prevent changes without a pull request)
 # Repository > Branch permissions > Add permissions > Branch name (=develop) , Restrictions (=Prevent changes without a pull request)
 # Repository > Settings > Repository details > Clear the checkbox to prevent forking of this repository
 # Repository > Settings > Pull requests > Requires N approvers (see to-be-reviewed-by list below)
 # Repository > Settings > Pull requests > Unapprove automatically on new changes
 # Repository > Settings > Pull requests > Requires all reviewers to approve the pull request
 # Repository > Settings > Branching model > Development (=develop)
 # Repository > Settings > Branching model > Enable automatic merging

I would like to allow pull requests only on brach develop:

*I believe that the problem is  that "Push latest changes from local to remote" is enabled and is not-editable option.* (see attachment 01.png)

Please note that the following option ("Push changes immediately to origin/develop") is enabled when I do commit, although I am not sure if it plays a role (see attachment 02.png)

The error message I am getting is:
remote: Branch refs/heads/develop can only be modified through pull requests.        remote: Check your branch permissions configuration with the project administrator.
Could you please advise on how to setup the pull-request only workflow in bitbucket using sourcetree ?

 

*NOTE:*

It seems that the same issue was described in SRCTREE-1798

Issue has been filed also here: [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/SourceTree-questions/allow-pull-requests-only/qaq-p/587001]

Would you be so kind to make this a high priority as while the hosted Bitbucket server that our company uses allows all requests only policy, but the SourceTree does not, which is confusing and this functionality is a must in establishing a workflow in a big corp. 

Would you be so kind to provide an estimated date for the fix ?

Please let me know if you need any additional information.

with kind regards,

Nikos
fields.summary: allow pull requests only

fields.description:
The file name text edit field in the Create Patch dialog is permanently disabled so the name can't be set.

Steps to reproduce:
 * Select a commit
 * Right-click and choose "Create Patch..."
 * Try to set a file name. You can't.
fields.summary: Create Patch action: can't set a file name

fields.description: I had SourceTree 2.4 version previously which stopped working with attached error message. I downloaded 2.5.1 but still I see the error.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not open

fields.description: The line numbers in the diff view are no longer correct.  They all restart at 0
fields.summary: Line numbers don't show in the diff view

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce 
I cloned a repository (having 2 submodules) and disabled the option *Recurse submodules* in the *Advanced options* before cloning. Then, selected one of the 2 submodules and clicked the *Open* option. After that, not only the selected submodule was cloned but also the other one, which was not my intention.

h3. Expected behaviour
SourceTree would only clone the selected repo

h3. Actual results
All the submodules got cloned
fields.summary: 'Open submodule' command opens all submodules

fields.description: When switching from the desktop to desktop, as soon as the SourceTree window becomes active it sometimes hangs so I have to force-quit it. This happens since upgrading to 2.5.1, didn't have an issue before at all. This is very annoying, of course, as it happens at least once or twice a day now.
fields.summary: Keeps hanging at times since most recent upgrade

fields.description:
I have multiple Bitbucket Servers... they are all connected to the same LDAP for authentication.
 
 When I try to configure multiple accounts with HTTPS authentication it won't let me.
 
 It says I already have an account configured with these authentication and protocol settings (screen shot attached).
fields.summary: Same username / password with multiple Bitbucket Servers?

fields.description:
Some people unfortunately insist on using spaces for indentation, so it would be nice if the built-in diff views had an option to visualise whitespace (spaces are vertically centred dots, and tabs are arrows, both light grey).

Visual Studio Code, and Qt Creator both have this option and it is great.
fields.summary: Visualise whitespace in diffs

fields.description:
Following with SourceTree Security Advisory email from May 10th. I deleted old sourcetree.app from my mac machine and downloaded the latest from Sourcetreeapp.com. However, while trying to open the newly downloaded app I am seeing the same error message asking to move to Sourcetree version 2.5.1+ (attached screenshot). Please help where can I download latest image from and how to get rid of this error.

OS = OS X El Capitan v10.11.6

JDK installed in local = 1.8.0_91
fields.summary: Problem with SourceTree Security Advisory Version Update for Mac

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Open a repo is SourceTree w/ multiple branches.
 # Select the *Merge* command from the *Repository* menu.
 # Drag the bottom of the resulting pane to change its height.

h3. Observed
 # -The top of the history view becomes unpinned from the top edge of its container.- Appears fixed in 2.5.3.
 # If the height of the pane is increased enough (a couple hundred pixels?), the container around the first checkbox in the _Options_ view begins to resize fluidly (see [^Screen Shot 2017-06-26 at 9.01.26 AM.png]).

h3. Expected

Only the history view resizes fluidly.
fields.summary: Stack view in merge pane resizes incorrectly

fields.description:
Many times I have a lot of changes in my working copy and I decide to commit these in a few separate commits.

 

To have these commits working, I would love to have the ability to stash only a few selected files to get rid of them temporarily, rebuild to see if the stuff works, and then commit.

 

Currently, there is only an option to stash all files. Stashing selected filed only is possible with Git in command line, however this is so impractical.
fields.summary: Shash selected files only

fields.description:
Sourcetree continually shrinks the description field for all commits in the graph view: 
 
 [https://www.screencast.com/t/k3ubpcGO\\|https://www.screencast.com/t/k3ubpcGO/] 
 Obviously, it's a recoverable bug, but I have to do it about 20 time per day so it does start to add up, and it's just an annoying polish bug that really should be addressed.
fields.summary: Description field always collapses and is unreadabl

fields.description:
I want to edit the global gitignore file for my account, but SourceTree opens it in TextEdit rather than my preferred application.

h1. Reproduction recipe
# Open the SourceTree Preferences dialog and go to the Git panel. Next to the Global ignore list field, click the “Edit file” button. SourceTree incorrectly opens the file in TextEdit.
# Confirm that I have set the file to open by default in another application.
## Open the file using the command-line utility:
{code}~/ $ open .gitignore_global{code}
Result: The file opens in BBEdit.
## Locate the file using Finder. It’s a dotfile and so hidden by default, but I have hidden files set to visible. Also because it’s hidden, you have to right-click and choose Open.
Result: The file opens in BBEdit.

h1. Extended cut
I don’t know all the other places SourceTree launches files in this way, but it should use the user’s preferred application for all of them.

h1. Environment
SourceTree-Beta Version 2.5.2 (109)
OS X 10.11.5 (15F34)
fields.summary: SourceTree should use the default application for opening the global gitignore (and all files)

fields.description:
Adding files to the global gitignore (usually) doesn’t trigger the automatic refresh, but it should.

h1. Setup
# In SourceTree, make sure “Refresh automatically when files change” is checked. Confirm this:
## {code}~/ $ mkdir demoIgnoreGlobal
~/ $ cd demoIgnoreGlobal/
demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ git init
Initialized empty Git repository in ~/demoIgnoreGlobal/.git/{code}
## Open ~/demoIgnoreGlobal in SourceTree. SourceTree correctly displays it as an empty repository.
## {code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ touch theBaz{code}
SourceTree will detect this file and automatically refresh (it may take a second or two), showing theBaz as unstaged.
## Confirm that command-line git sees the file:
{code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ git status
On branch master

Initial commit

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	theBaz

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track){code}
## {code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ echo theBaz > .gitignore{code}
SourceTree will detect this change, correctly showing .gitignore as unstaged and hiding theBaz.
## Now that we’ve confirmed that the auto-refresh does work, remove the local .gitignore.
{code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ rm .gitignore{code}
SourceTree correctly shows theBaz as unstaged once again.
# Confirm that the global .gitignore is set up correctly.
## {code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ git config --get core.excludesFile
/Users/<username redacted>/.gitignore_global{code}
## Open the SourceTree preferences pane, switch to the Git tab, and confirm that the path in the dialog matches the result of that command.

h1. Test
# {code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ echo theBaz >> ~/.gitignore_global{code}
Watch SourceTree for a while. Most of the time, theBaz will _not_ disappear. (It happened to me once, but I think I must have clicked something that triggered a refresh.)
# Click the file listing for theBaz. Double-click theBaz to have SourceTree open the file. SourceTree doesn’t refresh.
# Confirm that command-line git no longer sees the file:
{code}demoIgnoreGlobal/ $ git status
On branch master

Initial commit

nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track){code}

h1. Environment
SourceTree-Beta Version 2.5.2 (109) (per the About dialog)
fields.summary: Refresh automatically doesn’t detect changes to global gitignore
Can there be a pane to move some files to "temporary changes" that are just meant for development purpose and never to be committed
try

fields.description:
In the latest update you have introduced an Italian localization to SourceTree.
Unluckily it is filled with translation errors.

It is overtranlsated: a huge number of technical terms (all of git and gitflow terminology as feature, branch, checkout ecc) are translated into Italian, but no one uses those words in Italy, for these matters we use the English terms.
The effects is comical, mostly, but sometimes borderline dangerous: often I have to stop and think before selecting a menu item, for I am afraid I'll mess up my repo.
My advice is simply to get rid of the Italian locale, anyone in the app target has a good technical english, the localization is really useless.
fields.summary: Italian localization is riddled with errors

fields.description: I can Create and Delete Mercurial Bookmarks in SourceTree Mac, but cannot Move them. Would love to be able to do that without having to Delete and then Create.
fields.summary: Let us Move a Mercurial Bookmark in the Mac GUI

fields.description:
Unintuitive functionality - feels like a bug, could be "by design" !/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png!  however.
 # Create three commits: 

 # 
 ## 3 change file 'a' on a separate line
 ## 2 change file 'a'
 ## 1 file 'a', file 'b'
 # Single-select commit 3, then examine the 'diff' window
 ## You'll see changes for commit 3.
 # Multiselect commits 3 and 2, then examine the 'diff' window.
 ## You'll see changes for commit 3.

Expected to see all the changes for all the selected commits when multiselecting.

Attaching a tiny repo for what it's worth. Pick the topmost commit and look at the diff, it adds "tinkle" to a line. Then select the top two commits and you'll still see "tinkle" but not the "345" diff for the second-most recent commit. Expected to see both commits' diffs when multiselecting commits. IMAGES: 

Top commit:

!image-2017-05-17-15-06-49-939.png!

Second from top commit:

!image-2017-05-17-15-07-10-178.png!  Problem, both commits selected, see only top "tinkle" commit in diff window. Is missing my "345" difference (yes 345 is there but not a green line). STree is doing an 'exclusive' instead of 'inclusive' diff thingy here: 

!image-2017-05-17-15-07-21-820.png!
fields.summary: Multiselecting 2 commits is same as selecting 1 in History diff-er

fields.description:
The reasons I am raising this as a bug vs. a new story are: 
 [1] I did raise a story previously but it just disappeared and could not be found.
 [2] the issue I am raising can qualify as a "bug" because it is impeding normal operations

[Main Issue]: 
 Currently to view history of any arbitrary single file ("Log selected") cannot be done without some deep knowledge which can ONLY be obtained by reading some support blogs. And actually doing so requires way way too many steps.

[Suggested Solution]:
 [1] Make a stand-alone menu item "File history..." under menu "View".
 [2] Once clicked, user will have chance to enter a valid file-path into an input box and click on a "Go" button to launch the current "Log selected..." window.

[Further Suggestion]:
 If possible, can "Log selected..." window be launched via a direct Terminal command? Such as "soruceTree.exe my-project/my-file.js" ? This will allow user to either automate and view the "Log selected" window very quickly.

Please note that viewing history for a single file is such a fundamental feature, it must be promoted to be a first-class operation. I do enjoy using SourceTree - but I have spent a lot of extra time on this particular operation.  Deeply appreciated if a fix can be made.

Many thanks
fields.summary: "Viewing history for a single file" should be made into a first-class feature

fields.description:
If you hit the gear icon, and select "Convert All to SSH", SourceTree will append ssh:// to the beginning of each remote. git doesn't recognize this, leaving me having to fix each repo in my sourcetree list.

 

How remotes repo using SSH looks like:
{code:java}
ecrmac-100642:site2 rrudnicki$ git remote -v
origin git@bitbucket.org:rrudnicki/site2.git (fetch)
origin git@bitbucket.org:rrudnicki/site2.git (push)
{code}
Doing a git fetch/push/pull on terminal it works fine.

 

After converting remotes to SSH:
{code:java}
ecrmac-100642:site2 rrudnicki$ git remote -v
origin ssh://git@bitbucket.org:rrudnicki/site2.git (fetch)
origin ssh://git@bitbucket.org:rrudnicki/site2.git (push)
ecrmac-100642:site2 rrudnicki$
ecrmac-100642:site2 rrudnicki$
ecrmac-100642:site2 rrudnicki$ git fetch --all
Fetching origin
ssh: Could not resolve hostname bitbucket.org:rrudnicki: nodename nor servname provided, or not known
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
 
Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
{code}
The issue here is the correct syntax should be using a slash "*/"* after [bitbucket.org|http://bitbucket.org/] instead of "*:"*. The workaround for it would be change manually the "*:"* for a "*/"* before your account/repo name using the command git remote rm / git remote add commands.
fields.summary: Convert all to SSH breaks all repos

fields.description:
On the bottom edge of the Main Window, the hidden GUI for the Command History is always active, even in the case the history has been "hidden" from the Main Window. Therefore, resizing the main window through the bottom edge can result undesirably in no action whatsoever (if dragged downwards), or it can display the Command History area (if dragged upwards).

Put it another way: ST's GUI can defy my window-dragging intention by undesirably revealing the Command History area.
 # Launch ST (2.5 v104)
 # Ensure the *Command History is hidden* (Menu: View > Show Command History)
 # *Move mouse over the bottom edge* of the ST window, hover the cursor on that edge
 # Notice mouse cursor icon itself changes between three icons, *normal pointer*, *double-headed arrow*, and +*single-headed arrow with baseline*+, all within a one pixel radius as you slowly move the mouse around the edge. Try and carefully hover to {color:#654982}+*make the single-headed arrow with baseline cursor appear*+{color}. Note if you are using a pen-input device, like a Wacom tablet, which naturally drifts and is hard to keep still, this fine-grained icon selection may not be reliably possible.
 # *Drag* the Main Window's bottom edge Downwards (the middle of the bottom edge, to be more specific) 
 # Nothing will happen
 # To workaround: repeat the hover until *the double-headed arrow* appears
 # Drag the Main Window edge Downwards
 # The window will be resized as expected

I expected the main ST window to be resized in all cases when the Command History is "hidden". (That is why I initially categorized this issue as "Bug").

I would expect for the Command History drag-out area to be Discoverable through a pop-up region; a small bar indicating to me that I can click and drag the bar to show a hidden window. (This part of the issue is New Feature - but I still feel this issue represents buggy behavior - the command history edge breaks resizability of the window.) 

A workaround for this difficulty is to hover the mouse very slowly in a search-pattern over the edge, until the desired mouse cursor icon type appears. 

Another workaround is to use the corner to resize.
fields.summary: Resizing main ST window partly broken: either does Nothing or displays "Command History"

fields.description:
I accidentally resized the commits window and now cannot figure out how to revert the change

!atlas__Git_.png!

 

I tried updating but the problem remained
fields.summary: Merge window - Resized commits window and cannot resize back

fields.description:
On SourceTree for macOS, newest version (2.5.1), when trying to merge with right click-> "merge X into Y" -> after the confirmation pop-up shows, there is no option to force a merge commit. On SourceTree for Windows (v 2.x) there pop-up is the same, except for the 'force merge-commit' checkbox.
 
 Therefore, a fast-forward is done always when possible. This is incorrect behavior if, for example, we are following the git-flow rules.
 
 If I merge a branch through the "merge" button on top of view, I can force a merge commit, so that's a temporal workaround, however not really comfortable.
fields.summary: Lack of "merge commit event if can fast-forward" option

fields.description:
After updating from an older version to 2.3.2 I was greeted with a dialog asking me to create an Atlassian account. Some German texts are cut off since the labels are too short and/or not set up to wrap the lines.

I tried to attach the screenshots to this ticket but unfortunately that didn't work: JIRA posted the following error message after I tried to attach the screenshots:
{quote}JIRA could not attach the file as there was a missing token. Please try attaching the file again.
{quote}
I did try again. Same result. So I placed the screenshots on my server: [http://darkdust.net/files/sourcetree.zip]
fields.summary: Various localized strings are cut off

fields.description:
The normal workflow is: changing files > staging them > committing them

This should be reflected in the layout of the corresponding sections in SourceTree. I.e. from top to bottom.

The "Staged files" and "Unstaged files" tabs are however switched, which makes absolutely no sense.

Btw: Major competitors ([gitup.co|http://gitup.co/], [gitkraken.com|http://gitkraken.com/], ...)  have them in the correct order.
fields.summary: Add option to switch "Staged files" and "Unstaged files" tabs

fields.description: not a big problem, but it happened to me a couple of times that i had some "Icon<cr>" (where cr is the \n character) file and sourcetree don't handle it correctly
fields.summary: sourcetree doesn't handle files with <cr> character in the name

fields.description:
{color:#333333}{color}

I want to press a 'Find all remote forks' button inside sourcetree to fetch all remote forks.

I believe this would be tremendously helpful for users around the world who work on public git repos. please consider as some work for future / perhaps put in backlog. 

this script does this > perhaps you can cherry pick some logic.

[https://github.com/frost-nzcr4/find_forks]

 

consider that developers could avoid wasting time redoing work - other developers have already completed in other forks.
fields.summary: fetch all remote forks

fields.description:
I have a large number of repositories cloned, and i guess others are in similar situation too.

When i start the source tree, i see all of repositories in repository list, and it doesnt look good, i have hard time finding and organizing repositories.

 

It would be great if there was some way to group the repositories, so i can have a group of repositories for my open source projects, group of repositories for a company i am working on and another group of repository for another company. Also i can have groups for different directories for different branches.

Some thing like this

+--- Opensource work

-------- repo 1

-------- repo 2

+---- Company X

-------- repo 1

-------- repo 2

+---- Company Y

-------- repo 1

-------- repo 2

 etc

 

And i would be able to open/close the group

 

Either groups, or support for labeling repositories would work, if we add support for labeling repositories thn it should be possible to filter repositories by labels.
fields.summary: Support grouping/labeling repositories on repository list

fields.description:
# Clone repository from Bitbucket (https) that uses Git LFS
 # SourceTree prompts you to pull git lfs content
 # You are prompted to put in password twice
 # see "After Second Password Attempt". will stay like this till cancel, never pulling git lfs
 # after running git lfs through terminal, am able to pull normally.
fields.summary: Not able to pull Git lfs content through SourceTree when prompted

fields.description:
SourceTree prompted me for an upgrade from version 2.0.x to the latest version. Like many users, I am not keen on updates, because it often create unneeded stress and changes. A mail in my mailbox stressed that it was mandatory for "securiry reasons"

After the update, SourceTree refused to launch until I could specify a JIRA account, effectively preventing me of using it. Not specifying a user account would cause the app to quit. relaucnhing it would force me into specifying a user account again.

This is an extremely bad user experience for an upgrade.

First, SourceTree does not need an Attlassian account to work.

Second, I was not warned ahead of time that I would need this (free) account

Third, I had no way to opt out of the upgrade after having discovered this new requirement.
fields.summary: After update SourceTree refuses to work without a JIRA account

fields.description:
I have a lot of git repositories on my external server (neither GitHub nor Bitbucket) and I don't want to keep them all on my computer. When I remove a local repository from the disk, SourceTree shows that the repository is removed in the Repository Browser and can't do anything with it. I need to know remote URL to clone the repository back. So I have to write down removed repositories URLs to restore them later.

It would be awesome if SourceTree keeps repositories URLs when local repositories are removed. So I would have a list of my remote repositories right in the SourceTree app and would be able to clone any of them any time.
fields.summary: Keep remote repositories URLs for removed local repositories

fields.description:
SETUP:

I right-click a branch in the Sidebar list of Branches, I then click "Rename...".  I'm presented with a modal dialog box entitled "Rename Branch".  The edit field is pre-populated with the current branch name.

EXPECTED BEHAVIOR:

The contents of the edit field would be selected, so that I can type a new name, replacing the current branch name with one of my choosing.  When I'm done, I can use Enter or Esc to commit or cancel my change.  Alternatively, I can use the Tab key to cycle the highlight through the three controls present in the box - the edit field, the OK button and the Cancel button

ACTUAL BEHAVIOR:

The contents of the edit field are not selected, and the edit field doesn't have focus, so my typing goes nowhere.  Also, tabbing around doesn't cycle the highlighted control.  I can, however click on the edit field to place the cursor or highlight text.  Once this field is active, I can use Enter or Esc to commit or cancel my change.
fields.summary: The edit field of the "Rename Branch" dialog cannot be accessed via the keyboard

fields.description: If I change an URL for an existent repo on SourceTree and by mistake add a wrong URL it would be useful we get a notification about that so we can correct it.
fields.summary: Check for invalid URLs on ST

fields.description:
Every partial add of a file to the git index reloads the file pane (right), causing user to look context.

 

Steps to reproduce:

1) Edit a file in various locations

2) In Source Tree, in the left pane, go to "File status" and select modified file

3) The changes of the file will show up in the right pane. Scroll to the last change and select a line and select "Stage lines". (Or alternatively "Stage hunk" has same issue)

 

What happens:

Right pane is completely reloaded and jumps back to the top. User looses context and has to scroll down again.

 

Expected:

Staged lines are added to the index but scroll position within the file should stay the same.
fields.summary: Adding a single line of a file to the index reloads file view

fields.description:
SourceTree for Mac is affected by a command injection vulnerability in URI handling. The vulnerability can be triggered through a browser or the SourceTree interface.

*Affected versions:*
* Versions of SourceTree for Mac starting with  1.4.0 before version 2.5.1 are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
* Upgrade SourceTree for Mac to version 2.5.1 or higher from https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/

*Acknowledgements*
We would like to credit  Yu Hong  for reporting this issue to us.
 
For additional details see [the full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/jW2xNQ].
fields.summary: Command Injection (CVE-2017-8768)
Stuck on submodule commit dialog unable to cancel

fields.description:
To replicate:
1. Click Merge in the top bar
2. Select the Merge From Log tab if it isn't already selected
3. Move the mouse over the bottom right corner of the pop-up window.
4. Click and hold mouse button, drag mouse to the bottom right of the screen,
fields.summary: "Merge From Log" GUI expands and resizes incorrectly

fields.description:
It would be great were SourceTree to support QuickLook when rendering previews of changed files.

We do include various files in our repositories that are opaque when SourceTree is attempting to show what has changed.
 There are however QuickLook plug-ins for many of those files (various Omni products, Sketch, our native file formats).

It would be great to query QuickLook for previews for files SourceTree (for macOS) doesn't support natively!
fields.summary: QuickLook support in SourceTree preview

fields.description: When the *All Branches* option is chosen and the *Show Remote Branches* option is unchecked, we see just our local branches. If we check the _S_*how Remote Branches* option, then we see all the additional branches that exist on the remote(s). It would be nice to have an option to see local branches and their remote tracking branch counterparts.
fields.summary: Option to see local branches and their remote tracking counterparts

fields.description:
Whenever I want to drag and drop a file or multiple files between Finder windows, Sourcetree is stealing the focus and overlaps the Finder window, where I want to drop the files.

Happens on OS X El Capitan 10.11.6.
(We cannot upgrade OS X version due to usage of Adobe Applications, which are only supported up to El Capitan.)
fields.summary: Sourcetree stealing focus on drag & drop in Finder

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When trying to add a Bitbucket Server account to Sourcetree 2.5 (104), the *Save* button gets disabled. This happens for both SSH and HTTPS.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # In SourceTree, click on *Cog icon > Add accounts > Add*
 # In the 'Host' section select 'Bitbucket Server' and enter your URL. Note that the *Save* button is active
 # Enter your username. The *Save* button becomes disabled. No matter what you do now, the button will stay disabled and you won't be able to add your account

h3. Workaround

If you fill in all the fields (except the username) and leave the username for the end, the *Save* button will remain active and you'll be able to add your account.
fields.summary: Adding a Bitbucket Server account to SourceTree 2.5 in MacOS is not possible

fields.description:
I am using the latest SourceTree version 2.5(104).
When creating a PR for a branch it opens right in GitHub and even shows the right base branch, but no diffs are shown. When I open the PR from GitHub it works OK.
fields.summary: Creating PR does not work (shows no difference with base branch - GitHub)

fields.description:
This used to be present in the menu bar in the pre-2.0 days, but has been noticeably absent since (with no option to add it back).

 

For users that are constantly checking out new feature branches for PR reviews and such, it just seems odd that the user no longer has the option of placing the functionality back in the Menu Bar where it used to live.
fields.summary: Allow Users to Place Checkout / Checkout New Branch in the Menu Bar Again

fields.description:
My global .gitconfig file contains lines similar to this:

[commit]
 template = /Users/me/.git_message_template.txt

This file content something like :


{code:java}
 # If applied, this commit will...

 # Explain why this change is being made

 # Provide links to any relevant tickets, articles or other resources
{code}


When using command-line git, this causes the commit message to be populated with the contents of .git_message_template.txt. and after commit the line prefixed with # (comment) was removed. However, when committing via SourceTree, all lines are keep in commit message.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't remove comment in commit message

fields.description:
With our configured BitBucket integration the following does not work and doesn't give you an error message: 

1. Create local branch
2. Create several commits
3. Right-click on branch and choose "Create Pull Request..."

=> Nothing happens.
Pushing the branch to the remote and then do 3. again resolves the issue.
fields.summary: "Create Pull Request" does not work when the branch is not pushed to a remote yet

fields.description:
I read the release notes to SourceTree 2.5 (latest MacOS) and suddenly... I am one of those affected by Sourcetree asking me for my password sometimes three or four times for one simple operation.
 This is true for several machines.
 
 The one thing that just hit me is this, even Apple has had issues with my account and signing in the beginning of iOS development because I have an Umlaut in my name. ("Krauß"). That often causes trouble when trying to find the keychain by my name if encoding is not handled properly.
fields.summary: Frequent dialogs asking for password (keychain issue?)

fields.description:
When right clicking on a parent commit and selecting "Rebase children of *** interactively...", an error is displayed:

```

/Applications/SourceTree-Alpha.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/libexec/git-core/git-rebase--interactive: line 258: 14785 Killed: 9               '/Applications/SourceTree-Alpha.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' "$@"

Could not execute editor

```

 

This happens in SourceTree alpha 2.5.1 (106) with embedded git. Works fine in SourceTree beta 2.5 (101).

 

Thanks
fields.summary: Rebase children interactively broken

fields.description: Sourcetree for Mac has a setting "Window Restoration". I have set this to "Restore windows on startup" but it reopens every tab as a new window.
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not restore tabs when opening

fields.description: Something
fields.summary: testing

fields.description:
This issue is still present in SourceTree 2.5, albeit less severe. I can reliably reproduce it for certain hunks, but not for others. So far, my theory is that it depends on the size of the hunk: For small hunks, staging is fine, but for large hunks, it still causes a reset of the scroll position.

 

Attached are two screenshots, one just before staging the depicted hunk (the top one, fully visible), the other taken right after, with the scroll position reset.

 

Here is the text of my original report (for 2.3.2):

When using the "Stage hunk" button to stage changes for git, the diff view each time scrolls to the top. This is very annoying if I want to say, stage hunks 10 to 15 out of 20, as for each hunk I stage, I next have to scroll back where I was, stage the next hunk, and so on.

Note that sometimes, when I wait a moment longer after staging the hunk, the diff view flickers as if it was scrolled back to the top and redrawn *again* ...

This used to work flawlessly, but at some point in the past broke (unfortunately, I do not know whether it correlated with a SourceTree update).

I already have the "Refresh automatically when files change" option disabled in the preferences, as that also used to cause things to scroll at arbitrary times. But it is almost as if staging a hunk now ignores this setting... ?!?

 

This is *really* annoying, as it negatively impacts my usual workflow quite seriously. For now, I am back to using "git add -p", but I'd really prefer to use SourceTree for this again, as it also allows me to quickly stage or discared individual lines.
fields.summary: Staging hunk still causes diff view to scoll to top even in 2.5 (104)

fields.description:
It would be helpful to get an indication of the time of/since the last update to repo on the main SourceTree window.  Something like the enclosed, for example:

 

!SourceTree.png!
fields.summary: add "last change" to main window

fields.description:
When you press and hold the (+) button at the top of the window the split view option does not activate as in previous versions. 

If you press and hold the (+) button of the repository window, split View is activated as always, but it says that the "repo navigator" does not support split screen, so it is no longer possible to have both the repo window and the repo navigator window in split view.
fields.summary: Split view no longer available in the repo navigator window
